SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

evs.data.fileio.ohdfile.misc
Class HCalendar

java.lang.Object
  evs.data.fileio.ohdfile.misc.HCalendar

public abstract class HCalendar
extends java.lang.Object

A class that contains static functions for use with Calendar and Date objects. Primarily, it is used to convert Calendar objects to and from Julian hours. Also, it can be used to translate String objects of specific format to and from Calendar objects. It is important to realize that all of these methods assume GMT by default, and that Julian hours, herein, is assumed to be computed relative to hour 0 or January 1, 1900.

Lastly, the computeCalendarRelativeToPresent method takes a String of the form,

<+ or -> [number units] [number units] ...

where the spaces are purely optional. The number MUST be an integer and the units must be one of the Strings in the VALID_UNITS constant array below. If the passed in adjustment factor String is valid, the returned Calendar will be set to the current time adjusted appropriately by the adjustment String. If it is not valid, the null will be returned.


Author:
hank

Compute a Calendar object based on the Julian hours (since 1/1/1900 GMT, Midnight) The calendar returned is in GMT, and it **assumes** the jhour was computed in GMT!

Returns:

computeCalendarRelativeToPresent

public static java.util.Calendar computeCalendarRelativeToPresent(java.lang.String factor,
                                                                  double nV)
This routine can be used to convert a String of known format into a date, based on the system date. The passed in String is simply an adjustment factor string, used to adjust relative to the current time:

<+ or -> quantity unit quantity unit ...

where <+ or -> is either '+' or '-', and:

- quantity is a positive number,
- unit is either weeks, days, or hrs (not case sensitive)

Every quantity and unit may be separated by spaces, tabs, or newlines.

The returned Calendar is the current system time adjusted by the adjustment factor given in the String. A return of null implies and invalid factor string.

Parameters:
factor -
nV - the null value
Returns:
the calendar

computeIntervalValueInHours

public static int computeIntervalValueInHours(java.lang.String str,
                                              double nV)
Returns the time interval implied by the passed in string, after converting it to hours. It uses the computeAdjustFactor static method in this class.

Parameters:
str - String specifying the units.
nV - the null value
Returns:
The number of hours.

computeAdjustFactor

public static int computeAdjustFactor(java.lang.String num,
                                      java.lang.String unit,
                                      double nV)
This routine can be used to calculate a number of hours given by an adjustment factor specified by the passed in num and unit. The num and unit are:

num is a positive number,
unit>is a VALID_UNIT above.

If unit is either null or "", then it is assumed to be "hours". The returned Integer is the number of hours corresponding to the adjustment factor.

Parameters:
num -
unit -
nV - the null value
Returns:
the number of hours

computeJulianHourFromCalendar

public static int computeJulianHourFromCalendar(java.util.Calendar date,
                                                boolean gmt)
Given a Calendar, compute the Julian hour. If gmt is true, then we are to ASSUME the calendar is already in GMT, regardless of its true TimeZone. This allows callers to play around with a Calendar without actually paying any attention to its TimeZone, but just let it be GMT.

Parameters:
date -
gmt -
Returns:
Julian hour

                                    int dayofyear,
                                    int hourofday)
Compute the Julian hour based on the year (1900...), dayofyear (1..366), and hourofday (0..23) This is all in GMT (Z-time).

Parameters:

hourofday -

                                    int month,
                                    int dayofmonth,
                                    int hourofday)
Compute the Julian hour based on the year, month (0..11), day (1..31), and hour of day (0..23).
NOTE: MONTH STARTS AT 0!!!

Parameters:
year -
month -
dayofmonth -
hourofday -

convertStringToCalendar

public static java.util.Calendar convertStringToCalendar(java.lang.String str,
                                                         java.lang.String format)
Convert a string to a calendar based on a format. The format is a sequence of characters describing the format of the date string. For example: CCYY-MM-DD is a valid string, saying the first 4 digits is the year, 6,7 is the month and 9,10 is the day. Valid character codes: CC, YY, MM, DD, hh, mm, ss, TZC.
Default time zone is GMT!!! Unless the string passed in overrides it.
Returns null if one of the numbers in the date string is not valid.

Parameters:
str -
format -
Returns:
string calendar

parseDateComponent

public static int parseDateComponent(java.lang.String str,
                                     java.lang.String format,
                                     java.lang.String key,
                                     int defaultreturn)
                              throws java.lang.NumberFormatException
A wrapper function on HString.getKeyFromString which uses it for extracting a date component. If the component specified in the key is not present in the format, then this function will return defaultreturn. Otherwise, it return the characters from str in the same position as the key is in format, parsed into a integer.
THIS FUNCTION MAY RESULT IN A NumberFormatException!!!

Parameters:
str -
format -
key -
defaultreturn -
Returns:
date component
Throws:
java.lang.NumberFormatException

processTwoDigitYear

public static int processTwoDigitYear(int year2d,
                                      int todayyear)
Return the four digit year corresponding to the data card 2 digit year. This uses the windowing technique employed by NWSRFS (a window around current year, specified by Y2K_UB_WINDOW)!

Parameters:
year2d -
todayyear -
Returns:
four digit year
